fields.headline: Dramatic oversight
fields.bodyText: Nowhere in the debate about playwrights at the National Theatre (Letters, March 28) was a single female name mentioned - old or young. Maybe when the old stags and the new bucks have stopped clashing their antlers they might find time to address this problem, apparently invisible to them, but not to the 50% of the population who might expect better representation at something called the National Theatre. Mary Cutler Birmingham If the French people, as Kay Lacey (Letters, March 28) says, have not forgiven us for the 100 years war, then they are as ignorant as many English. That war was not between the English and the French, but between the dukes of Aquitaine, who also happened to be kings of England, supported at times by the dukes of Burgundy, against the French crown. DN Taylor Hebden Bridge, W Yorks The serious questions of James Dowson's activities aside (Anti-abortionists turn sights on school and hospitals in US-style campaign, March 27); he states that the Pope is "very adamant that this recreational sex education cannot be taught"; here speaks a celibate, the rest of us would recommend small tutorial groups and experiential learning. Martin Buggy Huddersfield, W Yorks I wrote to Marmite after I noticed a change in the consistency about 20 years ago (Letters, March 27). They fobbed me off with the old "It's a yeast product, so the consistency changes" line. Funny, then, that it's never changed back. Also, those rotten plastic tops get stuck. Jane O'Mahoney Launceston, Cornwall Have the feminists (Letters, March 27) noticed that even Mother's Day was only 23 hours long? DR Sethna Loughborough, Leics Abolish the future?
